title: ‘Culturally Diverse, Equal Opportunity Employer with amazing values’
pros: ANZ has amazing values. They have a great Pride Network which not only focus on the LGBTI employees but focus on diversity and inclusion for ALL employees. They are a super regional company with worldwide support for staff and its customers. ANZ has won home lender of the year for 13 out of 17 years. The training is second to none with ongoing support
cons: ANZ believes in their staff being highly skills across multiple areas of the business which is fantastic but workload can sometimes become a little heavy as you get upskilled.

title: ‘It used to be good, not anymore’
job_title: Services Consultant And Personal Banker (Split Role)
pros: Flexible working hour, employees share scheme, free uniform, free bank account fee.
cons: Work pressure, working overtime without getting paid on busy branch, too many young age or laziness managers lead to poor management, policies keep changing all the times.

title: ‘There are plenty of opportunities, work as a team and share your knowledge’
pros:
- Base on your best yearly performance, normally u’ll get rewarded extra money for ur hard work.
- When you acting as a Team Supervisor or doing some projects,  u also get extra  payments.
- I’ve gotten an incentives payment for extra hours
- I had fews of employees award 
- some other rewards 
- Balance between work and family ~ flexibility hours
cons: Every day you Have to face a new or different challenges and I loved those challenges

title: ‘Great people, management had no idea, got out as fast as I could.’
pros: The staff cared for their customers and each other
cons: Management had absolutely no idea, see Banking Royal Commission for multiple examples. Product over customer every time. Half of them should be in gaol!!!

title: ‘Having joined in the past 18momyhs, I have found my team and my role a great place to work and I have the satisfaction to deliver to our customer expectations’
pros: Strong culture and work life balance, working flexibly
cons: Processes are at time underinvested

title: ‘You will never be happier than working at a place like ANZ.’
pros: I would honestly say that working at ANZ was one the greatest opportunities I've had and will never forget. Starting from the work environment, people, team leaders up to things like pay rates, the vibe of everything and everyone there.
cons: There wasn't many challenges only being a sales representative, since I'm a person who enjoys more of a customer based role than dealing with sales.

title: ‘Glad I worked there once I got a good manager and I do recommend working there if you want to move up the chain of command.’
pros: They are very good with flexibility such as when I was at uni and had to change my roster every semester. I fortunately had an amazing manager who was very easy going if/when things were going on your personal life such as sick kids or car troubles.
cons: I LOVED being a teller and seeing the regular customers everyday but they were more interested in having everyone (staff) do everything (personal banker, teller, personal loans, and home loans) which I feel is really bad because I found that no one was really good at anything any more. Everyone knew the basics of things but I felt we were letting our customers down because no one specialised in anything anymore which caused problems. I wasn't interested in climbing the ladder, I wanted to stay as a teller and be the best teller possible.

title: ‘Working for ANZ has allowed me to develop skills and knowledge that I will always benefit from.’
job_title: Manager, Global Banking And Product Marketing
pros: A strong company that believes in promoting diversity and equal opportunity.
cons: There are always challenges when working for a global company, especially in the difference of procedures across various regions.

title: ‘Overworked and under appreciated ’
pros: Money and bonuses - I wouldn’t have stayed for as long as I did without. The group of people I worked with, opportunity to complete a data management project and implement Data Governance.
cons: Lack of clear and consistent strategy - every time I came close to implementing something it changed!, lack of resources, pushing people who already work more than 14hrs a day to do more, putting managers in place that don’t understand the detail and don’t want to, coming back from maternity leave and being looked down on by senior leaders for taking advantage of flexible working hours (even though I was working 14hr days!!), taking maternity leave and coming back to a mess that took months to clean up.

title: ‘ANZ is a bank I will always be loyal to and I would love to work there until I am retired.’
job_title: Manage Expense Data Support And Development
pros: ANZ is the best fastest growing bank in Australia. I love the career opportunities within Australia and globally. I am proud to be part of the company as company provides full support to their employees in professional front it has many branches across the world. So I have good opportunity to show my talent.
cons: Sometimes it can be challenging in setting boundaries and say no to business stakeholders.

title: ‘Wishing that banking still had integrity’
pros: The actual job is great as per job description
cons: Targets, constant staff turnover, too many chiefs, unless you live for your job you are considered replaceable . The focus is supposedly to satisfy customer needs but in truth you are expected to sell products or you're soon gone.

title: ‘ANZ was a pleasure to work for and if a suitable opportunity arose to work for them again I would happily do so.’
pros: You have the opportunity to work for and with some really great people that are very understanding and usually do their best to take care of you!
cons: Hitting the designated targets can be a little out of reach when the big decrease in foot traffic isn’t considered.

title: ‘Several years at ANZ I have had mostly positive experiences & made lifelong friends.’
pros: Lots of training, opportunity to advance in career, work/life balance is good for working mums. Set roster but overtime is usually available when other staff have annual leave/long service leave. The people are great, having worked in several ANZ branches most of the employees are lovely to work with.
cons: The targets are quite high, expect a lot from each customer. Targets for opening a certain number of accounts/credit cards & loans per week. Performance is monitored based on your sales activity - some staff excel in \"sales\" but lack basic people skills. It's hard to work in an environment where some people try hard but their enthusiasm for great customer service is not recognised, and they are told not to \"over service\" the customer instead open the accounts quickly & try to sell insurance/quotes to them and then serve the next customer. Trying to book annual leave when you actually want it is sometimes difficult, with all staff submitting their holiday preference 12-18 months in advance for each branch.

title: ‘Very positive from both a work and social aspect.’
pros: The people are friendly and like minded. Flexible working is promoted. Amazing client base. Close working relationship between bankers and advisers
cons: Office politics, restructures occur too often and difficult stakeholders can make project implementation difficult. Technology is a disaster!

title: ‘Typical slow moving corporate bank’
pros: Great perks on card and home loan rates/fees, supportive parental leave
cons: Slow processes, as well as many stay taking liberties on work from home opportunities. Most mid level staff only seem to be there for themselves and not for the good of their team or working to better the company.

title: ‘People with loud noise seems to be seen as asset to company and no real appreciation for efforts contributed. No equal opportunities and career advancement for genuine individual in this company.’
pros: Old management team appreciated staffs hard work and experiences shared among teams. People management retains great staffs with positive attitude and working beyond and above to succeed as a team.
cons: New management focuses only on top down approach with no consensus among teams.

title: ‘Good opportunities to learn and develop a career’
pros: Bonuses can be nice if you reach targets and outperform. Referrals are sent via branches. Access to good support systems. Good learning opportunities to build a career.
cons: Limitations on types of advice to be provided. Heavy compliance can be a hindrance to advice. Performance is measured based on national averages and targets across a wide area and include things out of ones direct control

title: ‘Over all it was a good experience. If you worked hard and asked for feedback you were rewarded and there was always room for career growth at ANZ.’
pros: They gave us heaps of training and there were many opportunities to practice before we actually took calls live. There was a lot of feedback so you knew how you were doing.
cons: The scheduling and shifts took some getting used to.

title: ‘ANZ is an organisation that treats customer facing staff incredibly poorly and is duplicitous by nature as it is 100% sales focused.’
pros: Flexible hours and ability to work from home when required
cons: Middle management place their own goals above their team members and customers

title: ‘Great place to work with leaders being more agile than ever before’
pros: Dynamic, leaders in the financial space
cons: A big organisation, with multiple layers of management - being changed though

title: ‘A rewarding challenge in an environment that lets you grow surrounded by wonderful and challenging people alike.’
pros: Diversity and equal opportunity is second to none. Despite often having to work long hours, ANZ offers great flexibility and work/life balance. There is a subsidised gym and plenty of health incentives. The salary is high and there are good bonuses.
cons: Technology is definitely a challenge, and there can be lots of red tape around getting things done. Some of management are not suited to their roles and that can have a negative impact.

title: ‘During recent restructure, my position became redundant,I miss working for ANZ.’
pros: Good environment, well equipped business, that looks after their staff. Senior management were always approachable. Health and Safety was always paramount. Relaxed environment. New ideas were always welcome.
cons: Only sometimes, best people are overlooked for for favorites.

title: ‘Overall, my experience has been a great one. I plan on scaling the corporate ladder :)’
pros: The people. My customers and colleagues are fantastic
cons: It has taken me a while, but i finally got the hang of balancing.  Sometimes being shown how to do some thing once and then being expected to remember how to so it was challenging

title: ‘Very satisfied with my job and the company I work for i.e ANZ !’
pros: Love working with a great team and very encouraging manager. The work ethos is very good and I love the work I do.
cons: Dealing with new customer every time and resolving their problems and looking for solution to their questions. And making sure the customer is happy and satisfied.
location: Wagga Wagga, New South Wales, Australia

title: ‘Excellent!’
pros: Excellent staff training and advancement in the corporate ladder. Promotes high level of adherence to bank's values. Customer service is top priority.
cons: Meeting the bank's expectations from its staff, that is to offer high level of customer service.

title: ‘Wonderful people and great technical challenges.’
pros: Always new technologies to learn. Great people to work with.
cons: Working with global colleagues can be difficult. The company lost a lot of its focus on employee engagement once Mike Smith took over from John McFarlane.

title: ‘Good for most part of my career, last months terrible with the manager and team i had, at the end yoir just another employee unless your a star!’
pros: Depends where your based. FOund working in retail my better time with the bank as opposed to working in Business banking. The idea in business banking great just not in my area and team. No one really cared about each other and the struggles. Too high expectations with not a lot of help besides computer based training.
cons: Sales targets were always a struggle. Even when they changed the way to make it sound 'where looking after the customer' same thing and same results expected just didn't way they approach it.

title: ‘Great company to work for.’
pros: Work life balance and lots of career opportunities.
cons: As a result of being a large financial  organisation there are lots of controls , extra sign offs. No different from any other large organisation.

title: ‘Supportive, people centric environment that has kept me interested for over 11 years.’
pros: Overall Culture of ANZ is dynamic, continually striving to make life easier for both internal and external customers alike.
cons: Like most organisations genuine \"career development\" opportunities are scarce across the board, but definitely on the radar.

title: ‘It helped m to grow not only as a banker but made me see things on many different perspectives on so many different levels and made me a better person and so appreciative of everything.’
pros: Great people to work with making it a good experience. Plenty of  opportunities to grow and develop. Good Team Leaders and management.
cons: The only issue that i can say is that systems are quite laggy and tend to slow down and crash when your on a call. But when its running smoothly, its flawless

title: ‘I loved it so much and you could see by the years I have worked there.’
pros: I worked for twenty seven years .. the managers I worked under was very understanding and helpful .. staff was also very helpful and friendly but occasionally some can be moody.. that's human..enjoyed the friendly work ethic
cons: I always had opportunities where I was given a task and had to solve the issue which placed me in a very exciting situation where I would analyze and action the task to get  results ..  where my customer is happy and so does the bank 's image

title: ‘A great company to work for ’
pros: Big focus on work/life balance. Great parental leave policies and flexibility when returning to bring to work. Lots of opportunities to learn new skills and move up the ranks quickly of you prepared to do the work. Focus on customer service, no sales targets. Great perks including and extra week of leave a year after 3 years service.
cons: Systems can be frustrating. Often have to go through to other teams based overseas for assistance.

title: ‘A clearer longer term plan for Institutional is required - Senior Executive changes lead to directional and strategic changes resulting in frustration and lost opportunity  / waste.’
job_title: Ex Global Head TB Business Control & Delivery
pros: Salary package was very good (but you have to earn every cent and this included making staff redundant...an intensely personal and stressful thing to action and / or be on the receiving end of such a decision).
cons:
The ongoing cost cuttings , including staff reductions / redundancies.
The diversity agenda has gone too far and needs to be carefully repositioned to ensure equality and the best person gets the job.
The bonus structure needs reducing and being replaced with higher salary / lower bonus and more long term equity / shares instead.

title: ‘People are friendly. Company is mired in bureaucracy & process. Conservative culture that discourages stepping outside of process - even when it results in a better outcome.’
pros: Good pay. Suitable for people who like structured environments (i.e. emphasis on processes, documentation & meetings).
cons: ANZ is committed to off-shoring its back-office and administrative functions (Finance, IT, etc). Don't expect a career at ANZ if you are in these functions - you are just keeping the seat warm until the role can be transitioned.

title: ‘Beginning was great towards the end very upsetting’
pros: I have always worked with some really great people and have made some great friends thru the working environment. Like all things these change and by change it’s usually with management, more particularly at branch level, can be unsettling. I have been in banking for over 20years.
cons: Keeping up with the changes and expectations on usually monthly basis, trying to do your job as best u can with limited staffing and support. Having to be so organised that leave has to be planned out 12 months ahead and often Longer incredibly frustrating

title: ‘A great company to work for, but still more room to improve.’
pros: The company is a great company to work for overall. The people culture is really great, and you get quite good support from your line manager.
cons: When it comes to internal recruiting,  theres alot of competition inhouse. It can help if you have contacts in the relevant departments to move forward.

title: ‘Great place to work.’
pros: Great opportunities and a great team environment.
cons: Making targets can be challenging at times but with a great support network you are always learning new ways to identify leads.

title: ‘Looks after you well and if you work hard even better’
pros: Very good environment, friendly and inclusive. Opportunities to grow if you make it known
cons: Can be a bit political and at times slow to react.

title: ‘Excellent opportunity for those willing to put in the hard yards’
pros: You were generally rewarded for working hard. Plenty of opportunity as long as you were willing to move. Poor performers were usually exited quickly. Some very good senior leaders.
cons: Smaller branch locations were challenging. i.e noone in your branch could help and sections of help desk are overseas. Senior Personal Banker and Manager expectations are high, other banks dont expect these roles to complete home & business lending. But the skills you learn with this can take you places. Having worked in other financial institutions i would say the pay at ANZ does support the additional responsibilities.

title: ‘To advance in my chosen segment I have had to go back to Uni and, as I am wanting to change from Retail to Commercial, ANZ are not supporting my study needs.’
pros: I have met some wonderful people and my peer colleagues have been very supportive of my study commitments
cons: IT is a very big issue, no where near up to par of the other big 4, which makes providing excellent customer service difficult, so I have learnt to work around this issue.

title: ‘Rewarding and enjoyable.’
pros: Main office in Melbourne is well designed. Work area is neat, orderly and well equipped.
cons: Very competitive work environment. You always have to be on your toes and able to network with colleagues to get ahead faster.

title: ‘Satisfactory’
pros: Good benefits for new parents, such as parental leave, and financial help with daycare during the first months back after parental leave. Good opportunities to get training and move within the company. Extra super contributions for women to address the gender gap.
cons: A lot of grand ideas from the top that don't quite work practically on the floor.

title: ‘Good Company to work for and grow’
pros: Ability to work on Enterprise level projects and programs on latest technologies.
cons: Too many vendors and inability of ANZ Managers to take decisions properly. Most of them are non Technical Managers who take the role of Technical PMs and Technology managers thereby making improper judgement

title: ‘A good global organisation to have a great experience!’
job_title: Team Leader - FX & International Banking Services
pros: Work life balance has been good at least in my role. I was given a lot of autonomy to carry out my tasks and I was extremely happy at the outcomes I produced. It is a large organisation where you get a lot of talent and experience along with exposure which probably may not be available in a smaller organisation. Therefore, you are able to rub shoulders with people in high positions and have the elevator pitch!
cons: Growth opportunities were stunted. In the name of gender equality, people were selected based on \"whom they know\" rather than \"what they know\". Hence, I would think the rationale for recruitment should be unbiased, based on skills and ability of a person to deliver to set objectives of the organisation. Streamlining of systems, cutting out middle men in the scheme of a clustered hierarchy would be advantageous to the customer, to the organisation and to its employees.

title: ‘I have been in finance almost 13 yrs, ANZ was the only employer i have worked for where everything was fair and equal. I was never discriminated for my tattoos the girl that sat next to me interviewed with a Mohawk but we were never treated any different ’
pros: Equal opportunity. Fair and safe working environment. Recognition for your work that makes u feel valued.
cons: Just striving to do better, the performance and quality of work was always above the average i have seen else where.

title: ‘Great place to work!’
pros: Culture, Work life balance, career opportunities and management
cons: IT - has been offshored and it's so difficult to get anything done. Things take so long and constant system issues. Seems that ANZ hasn't invested in their technology and systems for many years!

title: ‘Good place to work if you like being kept on your toes’
pros: Flexible working arrangements are fantastic. Head office and other main offices very modern with great amenities.
cons: Not enough focus from upper management on front line issues. A lot of money wasted on poor decisions and short sitedness. Kind of like working with politicians...only looking to the next election. Or in our case, bonus.

title: ‘Enjoyable but sometimes quite a challenge.’
pros: The variety of the work and the other staff. Variable shifts made easier for the work life balance and enabled me to look after my child. Very flexible.
cons: Old computer systems, support network /HR was based in Bangalore so the languave barrier was an issue.

title: ‘Stable and steady’
pros: Staff benefits, and also my team leader. ANZ the brand is reputable and trustworthy, therefor people trust when you deal with them. Training for multiple products
cons: Staff turn over for our department and the sales numbers, being unrealistic for the products we sell.

title: ‘A great experience to build upon to further any career aspirations’
pros: It was a great atmosphere to work in due to the on-going training and the team structure which rewarded those who were an SME and wanted to gain leadership experience. Additional skills and a high performance was rewarded with great bonuses.
cons: The work-life balance can be difficult in a call centre environment as it is very dependant upon stats and productivity.

title: ‘A good place to work althought the current direction is not one in which I would go, we still have a dedicated team and environment.’
pros: The people we work with is what keeps most people in a role. We have a great number of people here who work well together and part of the reason we stick around.
cons: Management and the lack of ownership. Deadlines are unrealistic and do not take in to account current limitations of systems and requirements.

title: ‘ANZ was a fun place to work as a teenager, a good introduction to working life.’
pros: Good team morale. Sociable place to work. I enjoyed the fact there were a lot of young staff members my age - we all got along well.
cons: Frequent changes in management was sometimes unsettling.

title: ‘Bank financial planning has a poor reputation for a reason.’
pros: Lots of customers mean heaps of opportunities, unfortunately the constant reduction of support makes it near impossible to provide a good service.
cons:
Move to \"digital\" servicing of customers means a poor experience for customers and \"cookie cutter\" basic advice.
Management have little current experience of the business beyond auditing, theory or outdated advice experience, yet are the first to try to tell you how to do your job.
All the good staff who are able to walk into other jobs leaving behind less to try to manage the increasing demands of managers who rarely leave their ivory towers and run the business via spreadsheets and constant emails asking why you are not doing more sales and more use of their multiple digital tools that don't \"talk\" to each other.
Any support to help with administration is continually reducing.

title: ‘It was great!’
pros: Great work life balance
cons: I did not experience any challenges.

title: ‘A great company to work for overall.’
pros:
Great team environment, lots of options to progress in career. 
very adaptable/understanding to your personal needs/situation.
cons: Staff shortages are always challenging, dealing with aggressive customers is  difficult also but can be overcome.

title: ‘Always learning new and exciting things.’
pros: Really well managed and you can always feel comfortable working with different staff as everyone is so friendly. Always feeling like you have helped every customer you serve to the best of your ability.
cons: Learning new procedures, travelling around to different branches, sometimes over coming difficult obstacles eg. Customers, training courses.
location: Central Coast, New South Wales, Australia

title: ‘Although I don't work for ANZ anymore I have no regrets.’

The working environment was always very positive and the staff welcomed me with open arms and took me under their wings to teach me skills such as customer service, banking processes and terms.
cons: Having to deal with the occasional bad customer, it had the ability to ruin your day and really upset you.

title: ‘Interesting yet challenging’
pros:
Flexibility and career development. 
Good team work and environment 
Constantly updates on skill builders.  Rewarded for meeting targets
cons:
Compliance and keeping up to date with the latest information and products. 
Being able to succeed and over achieve goals.

title: ‘Very professional staff at head office and high standards are expected from individuals.’
pros: Modern and functional office fit out.
cons: No work / life balance in reality for rank and file.  Some flexibility is offered in exceptional circumstances, or if you happen to fall into one of the diversity groups.

title: ‘A great place to work for but the standard big corporate obstacles still exist.’
pros: Great culture, no jerks, you get to work with talented people on large projects that touch many Australians.
cons: Speed to market is slow. Understand that things often develop at a glacial pace and will be shelved for reasons beyond your control.

title: ‘Perseverance and truth to oneself should always prevail!’

As ANZ is a very large organisation with numerous divisions and sectors for individuals wanting change or the the ability to challenge themselves opportunities are abundant.
They have amazing staff benefits and most importantly they believe in giving back to the community
cons: At times a work life balance is not always balanced. Banking is also predominantly male oriented so when your a mother with children at times your ability to contribute and juggle family and work commitments can be overlooked by the fact that your a mother and a woman

title: ‘Good place but you will get to a point where progression will be halted and you.will be stuck until the changing of the guard’

title: ‘Challenging, yet rewarding.’

title: ‘Great company to work for. Work/life balance has been achievable.’

title: ‘My time at ANZ has provided me with exceptional customer service skills that I will continue to use throughout my career.’

title: ‘Currently not a great place to be an employee.’

title: ‘Hollow existence, wondered why I was working there.’

title: ‘I would not move to a mobile lending unless you’re desperate.’
pros:
Great hours , but more flexible than working for the bank directly as you’re working for a franchise of the bank. The franchise owner dictates the flexibility that you get with the job. 
You don’t have to hard sell anything lesser sales pressure than the bank.
More emphasis on learning different dimensions of a loan deal . So gaining in-depth knowledge about lending is good.
cons: Small business ,no job security, I got made redundant in just a few months of joining anz mobile lending as an admin staff. loan writers have income based mainly on commissions not a regular base pay. At least most of the times. The most worrying thing is that your success depends on the franchise owner who may or may not be a go getter .  If they are very motivated then franchise does well. But if they’re lazy then it can take a toll on your job security as there may not be enough business to service .
